Wagner Graduate School of Public Service      School of Continuing and Professional Studies      School of Law      School of Medicine      Silver School of Social Work      Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development      Tisch School of the Arts                                         Search        go                                                               New York University              New York University              Office of the Bursar                                                              eSuite Information                                         Login to eSuite                                   Invite Parents to eSuite                                FAQs                                E-mail Notification                              Electronic Check Payment                                Verify Financial Clearance                          Waive Health Insurance                                    Billing Schedule                                        NYU eSuite Features                                                                                         Payment Information                                     Loans and NY State Tap Awards                                     Tuition and Fees                                     Your Account                                     Refunds                                      Tax Topics                                           Forms                                           Services                                               Home        |        eSuite Information                 |         Student Health Insurance                                                                    If your statement of account includes a Student Health Insurance Plan fee and you have completed or plan on completing the online enrollment and waiver process, you should deduct this amount when making your payment.     If you are covered by health insurance and intend to request a waiver of NYU’s mandatory student insurance coverage, please complete the Student Health Insurance online waiver process on the Student Health Center website (On the right-hand side, click the brown box "Waive the Student Health Insurance Plans").      How to Waive Health Insurance:     Insurance waivers or changes in plan enrollment must be made online via the Student Health Center website . (On the right-hand side, click the brown box "Waive the Student Health Insurance Plans")     The enrollment and waiver process must be completed at the beginning of each academic year. Correspondence submitted to the Office of the University Bursar cannot be processed.     For more information about the insurance plans and the online enrollment and waiver system, contact:     Student Health Insurance Services     NYU Health Center     726 Broadway - Suite 346     New York, NY 10003-9580     212-443-1020      health.insurance@nyu.edu      or visit their website at www.nyu.edu/shc

How to Get Rid of a Monument and Replace It    | German | NYU                                                                                                                                                     Back to Previous Page         How to Get Rid of a Monument and Replace It: A Contribution to the Memory Culture of Weimar Germany     The long nineteenth century suffered from Denkmal-Manie , monument mania. As a result, the short Weimar era inherited thousands of monuments, had to take care of them, deal with them, get rid of them. At the same time, the 1920s were forced to erect even more monuments, this time not to the Great Dead White Males but to a collective of three million dead white males. The period needed not only more but also different types of memorial sites. How did modernism contribute to this task? Wolfgang Kemp 's lecture How to Get Rid of a Monument and Replace It: A Contribution to the Memory Culture of Weimar Germany tries to show how Weimar Germany overcame the nineteenth-century concept of the monument stylistically as well as practically, especially in those cases where existing monuments were either added to and commented upon or replaced by new creations. The Lebenslüge , the intrinsic fallacy of the monument, is its claim to eternity. Weimar’s creative contributions to memorial culture did not survive 1933. Wolfgang Kemp was born in Frankfurt/Main in 1946. He studied art history, German literature, and philosophy in Tübingen, Rome, Münster, and Bonn. He earned his Ph.D. in 1970, his "habilitation" in 1978. He has been assistant professor at the University of Bonn and full professor at the universities of Kassel, Marburg, and Hamburg, and has served as Arts Council Lecturer at UCLA, as Volkswagen professor at Harvard, as Getty scholar at Santa Monica, as visiting professor at the Central European University Prag, and as fellow at the Wissenschaftskolleg Berlin. Presently he is a senior professor at the Leuphana University Lüneburg. Among his numerous books on the history of photography, reception aesthetics, narratology, and the history of architecture are two publications published in English: The Desire of My Eyes: The Life and Work of John Ruskin (New York-London, 1991) and The Narratives of Gothic Stained Glass (Cambridge, 1997). His latest book is Foreign Affairs: Die Abenteuer einiger Engländer in Deutschland, 1900 bis 1947 , Munich 2010. Kemp is a regular contributor to newspapers and journals like Die Zeit , Süddeutsche Zeitung , Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung , and Merkur . Events at Deutsches Haus are free of charge. Please let us know which event you would like to attend by sending us an email to deutscheshaus.rsvp@nyu.edu . Space at Deutsches Haus is limited, please arrive ten minutes prior to the event. Thank you! (Photo: Walter Gropius, Denkmal der Märzgefallenen [ Memorial to Those Killed in the Kapp Putsch ], Weimar, 1922.) How to Get Rid of a Monument and Replace It: A Contribution to the Memory Culture of Weimar Germany is presented in collaboration with NYU's Department of Art Histoy. It is also a DAAD-sponsored event.                                                                                              Back to Top
